module.p: do your, thy is the second person singular possessive determiner, related to the personal pronoun thu you, thou.

Examples from Gairm –
[...] Cha robh e duilich tigh Maireid a lorg. [...] Bha Mairead ’na suidhe ann an cathair ris an teine is plaide timcheall air a glùinean. Bha Màiri a’ deanamh na dìnneir. Dh’ innis e dhaibh gur esan an duine a sgrìobh thuca, a dh’ fhaighneachd am b’ urrainn dha a thighinn. “Ai, ai,” arsa Màiri, “’se am maighstir-sgoile a fhreagair do litir.” [...]
[...] It was not difficult to find Margaret’s house. [...] Margaret was sat in a chair by the fire with a blanket around her knees. Mary was making the dinner. He told them that he was the man who had written to them, asking if he could come. “Aye, aye,” said Mary, “it was the schoolmaster that replied to your letter.” [...] td. 169–70, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn the letter that you wrote and sent
